column4: Hello. I've been having an issue with my laptop ever since upgrading to Ubuntu 10.10 from 10.04. Whenever I boot the latest kernel (the one that came with 10.10) I don't see anything on the screen. The system appears to be booting normally (judging by hard disk activity), it's just that I never get anything on the screen. The only way to boot my system (and have a display) is to use an old kernel left over from 10.04. My system
is a laptop (HP Elitebook 2730p) running intel graphics.
my system doesn't use an nvidia card, and neither of those two solutions worked.
it works with other chips too.
if you boot to root recovery mode, then run: su foo    replace foo with your username, then run:   startx    do you get a desktop?
Recovery mode shows me some text on the screen for a bit, then goes blank.
ok then run:  less /var/log/Xorg.0.log     it will give clues

I should add that I've tried the latest mainline kernel builds, and the current mainline (2.6.35.4, that matches the current Ubuntu kernel) also does not work, but the next kernel (2.6.35.7) does work.
but then my VGA out does not work.
then get an xorg.conf file rocking and it will :)
what would my xorg.conf have to do with anything when if I change kernels it works fine? Like I said, when I use the old kernel from 10.04 everything works just fine.
if your video card doesn't work, it may be udev failing to detect the settings. So you can use an xorg.conf file to TELL the system what to use and it should work
you cn run:   sudo Xorg -configure   then run:  sudo nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf    then read online to find sample files / code
When I try Xorg -configure, I get "Server is already active for display 0". The system is running right now with the display not working and I'm accessing it via ssh.
i believe it makes the file in $HOME
either way, you need the file /etc/X11/xorg.conf to be setup nice
